event: First evidence of settlement by Saladoid-Barrancoid peoples from South America.
Arawak and later Carib peoples inhabit the island.
Christopher Columbus sails near the region during his first voyage.
Portuguese explorer Pedro a Campos visits and names the island 'Los Barbados'.
First permanent English settlers arrive and establish a colony.
First Barbados House of Assembly convened, one of the earliest parliaments in the Americas.
Sugarcane introduced, transforming Barbados into a wealthy plantation economy dependent on enslaved Africans.
Slavery abolished in the British Empire; enslaved people in Barbados are emancipated.
Major labor riots lead to political reforms and the emergence of trade unions.
Barbados gains full independence from the United Kingdom on November 30.
Democratic Labour Party wins election; David Thompson becomes Prime Minister.
Freundel Stuart becomes Prime Minister following Thompson’s death.
Mia Mottley becomes Barbados’s first female Prime Minister.
Barbados becomes a republic, removing Queen Elizabeth II as head of state and inaugurating its first president.
